snippet: President Obama and Mitt Romney confronted what one feared and the other hoped was an altered campaign after a debate in which Mr. Obama’s performance was widely panned.
abstract: Pres Obama and Mitt Romney confront an altered campaign after their first debate, pounding new urgency into what is shaping up as a wide-open final sprint to Election Day; Romney's senior aides warn staff members and donors that the race is hardly won, but acknowledge that debate reversed the sagging morale of their campaign; Obama, universally judged to have underperformed, vows to argue more forcefully against his opponent's extreme conservative policies.

byline.original: By JIM RUTENBERG and PETER BAKER
byline.contributor: Mark Landler contributed reporting from Madison, Wis.; Ashley Parker from Fishersville, Va.; and Jeff Zeleny from Denver.

lead_paragraph: President Obama and Mitt Romney confronted what one feared and the other hoped was an altered campaign after a debate in which Mr. Obama’s performance was widely panned.

headline.seo: For Obama and Romney, Campaign Gains New Intensity in Debate’s Wake
headline.main: Campaign Gains a New Intensity in Debate’s Wake
headline.print_headline: Campaign Gains A New intensity in Debate's Wake
